body.p:
In Rachel's letter to Abby I scrawled a few lines, but
as Mr. Moses does not go till tomorrow I have resolved,
to write a little more in detail on the matter just now engrosses
naturally a good deal of my attention. The congregation consists
of about 48 members, seven or eight of whom are not in town
or perfectly in a ?. I or Mr Lyons may be counted sure;

If at meeting which however is doubtful whe-
ther they will attend

In all forty four members Absent and I believe no with us
Joseph J. Andrews & David G. Seinar; Raphael De Cordova; absent Jacob De Lan?, and
Levi M. Goldsmit, who if present would be for me, and be certain
at meeting. Of those ten put down for Lyons, it is possible but
hardly likely that Joseph & E. L. Moss will not be present; and the
Cohens, altho' they are somewhat bitter against me, may perhaps be
gained, if Mr. Gratz can get a chance of speaking to them after the
Lyons have done all they can. Joseph Cohen is in my favour, but
Abraham has somehow conceived an opinion that I have slighted
him, but I can freely say, that it is without foundation. He has
? me for about two years, and I never once saw him even
at his own house during all this time. No doubt some expenses
have been busy with him as well as with others, and he is about
such a man, as can be influenced of his pride is flattered. His
brothers hardly dare to disobey him, so that if they will not vote
for Lyons they will perhaps stay at home, unless Mrs Gratz
& her brother, or I have mentioned already can induce them to
do as they should and would do, were it not for the friendship of
Samuel Lyons.__Old Mr. Nathans is calculated on by them,
but I hardly think, that he has authorized them to use his name,
on the contrary his expressions are often the whole in my favour.
Altamont Phillips never was for me, altho' to all appearance there
never was a difference between us. Plock once owed me fifteen
Dollars for 18 months, and because he had to pay he is angry
there four pay. Dreyfous never was for me; why I never heard.
The brothers Asch last year were busy to cut my salary down
and thought them at variance with the Lyons' have since been
flattered over. Mr. Moss & his sons are likewise his son in law D.
Samuel & his brother are of course for the family.__But those on my

side put down on certain have been uniform supporters except Jacob
Phillips & Elias Hyneman, as also Joseph Phillips & I. J. Levy, who last year
gave such votes as caused all the present difficulty; of them four
had supported Abraham Hart's resolution, and not been fooled by Mr
John Moss I would have been elected for three years; but Mr. M. pro-
fessing that he never wished to see me out of office, they believed him,
and were caught in the cunning trap of annual elections, in order
as was said to keep the officers defendant, but in truth to make
room for Lyons. S. Morris has been friendly, though I know not whether
he ever gave a vote for me, I rather think the opposite is the case.
Isaac B. Phillips never attended meeting, but now he has
been roused by the monstrous injustice the Moss family intend.
Simon Gratz likewise was never present at an election these 8
years, altho' it is said he has now expressed his intention of
attending. David & Jacob Nathans, son of Isaiah may perhaps be
brought to the meeting by David Peroa, as also Samuel M.
Solomon, who is counted on by Lyons; Lewis Allen I call doubtful
because he is a brother in law of Lyons, and has not said any
thing from which his intentions can be known. Mr. Elkin never
goes to meeting and then he cannot be depended upon because
he speaks fair to all. Jacob Gratz altho' a staunch friend
has latterly almost withdrawn from congregational business & it is
doubtful whether he will be in town and of whether his sister can
make him go down; yet doubtless he will be roused, and if so, he
will cast a vote in my favour.__B. Eylinge? is lame of grat?,
but yet if urged by my friend may go for me, or otherwise for
Lyons; he is like Elkin smooth spoken. Isaac Moses & Isaac
Hays never go to meeting, yet Miss Gratz may induce them to
attend for that day.—Zalegman Phillips has never been for me,
and even if he votes for me, he may do it in such a manner as to
destroy all good effects from it. Aaron Levy is also very doubtful, altho'

he is said to have spoken in my favour._ Remember Etting is calculated in for Lyons
because I would not attend the funeral of his grandchild; yet I believe this
to be false, as he would hardly so much offend his relatives, who always have
been kind to him; yet I should think he will not go to meeting. His son
Gratz you know has been crazy, and if he is even well, it is hardly to be
supposed that he will dare to expose himself to the excitement of a
public meeting. I candidly believe that I have given you a fair statement,
and you will see that Lyons will have certain from 8-10; I about 14,
doubtful when present 19; doubtful whether they will come 10; now if we
divide these 20 and give him 20, the rest for me 24; it is certainly; by no means ascertained who will be elected; but if there is a
full meeting, it is not likely that he can be carried. The
only fear is a thin meeting, when 12 or 14 determined men
can do as they please. But persons have so often publicly said,
that Mr. Lyon's conduct was shameful, that one would suppose
in reason, that it would unite all, who are in my favour; but time
only can show. He may be elected, but if he is, it is by management
and such tricks as he must be ever ashamed of._They have also av
owed to get scholar for him, without asking me, whether it would
interfere with my interest._Last Sundry? week I called at Mr.
Allen's and left word, that if Mr Lyons would let me see his certificates
I would let him read. The certificates were left in Mr A's hands, never.
theless? they continued running to members, and at length obtained g?
Even to Sol. Moses they sent Joseph Moss & Isaac Phillips, not daring
to go themselves; but he told them, they ?ebah belong to me, and
I alone have the power to dispose of the prayers. The signers to the
petition requesting the Parnass to appoint (whether I would or not) were Mr Nathans,
E. L. Cohen, T. Samuel, Hyman Pollock, E. Hyneman, A. Elkin, Aaron Asch,
B. Lytinger & I think Aaron Luz; but I am not certain. Hyneman & Nathans
declared they merely did it to give him a chance, but nothing further. He read
